title: Present Perfect Tense vs. Present Perfect Continuous Tense

content.text: There are many differences between present perfect and present perfect continuous tense. We are going to learn about these in this tutorial. It will be easier to compare and understand these two tenses after knowing the differences.
Present Perfect Tense vs. Present Perfect Continuous Tense
content.name: txt1

content.text: MEANING: We use the present perfect simple with action verbs to emphasize the completion of an event in the recent past. We use the present perfect continuous to talk about ongoing events or activities that started at a time in the past and are continuing up until now.t There is often a difference in meaning: We use the Present Perfect Simple mainly to express the connection of a past action with the present so that we can emphasize the result, while we use the Present Perfect Progressive to emphasize the duration or continuous course of action.
content.name: 7l52

content.text: The construction of the present perfect continuous tense differs from the present perfect tense. Here we have:

content.class: bg-blue-100  text-2xl  grid grid-cols-2 items-center border-4 border-blue-500

content.text: Subject + Has / have (auxiliary verb present simple) + been (past participle form of 'be' verb) +  (main verb + ing)
content.name: FQOi

content.text: Subject + Has/have (auxiliary verb present simple) + past participle (third form of the main verb)

content.text: Example
content.name: EWP4

content.text: He has stayed here.
content.name: s7Cr

content.text: Here 'stayed' happens to be the past participle form of the main verb 'stay'. And 'has' is the auxiliary verb of the sentence. So, we need an auxiliary verb â€˜hasâ€™ or â€˜haveâ€™ along with the past participle form of the main verb to form a present perfect tense. The past participle form of the verb is also known as the third form of the verb. The auxiliary verb form is to be in the simple present form.
content.name: r0ot

content.text: Example
content.name: rG1Q

content.text: I have finished writing.
content.name: TcgA

content.text: Example
content.name: wfR9

content.text: It is evident from the construction that we form the present perfect continuous tense with the present form of auxiliary verb (have/has) along with the past participle of 'be verb' (been). And at last, the main verb + (-ing) is there to denote an action in progress
content.name: euKl

content.text: Example
content.name: MbMe

content.text: I have been feeling sick lately.

content.text: To construct the negative form with present perfect tense, then the word 'not' will be between the auxiliary verb and the main verb. That means 'not' is placed between 'have' and 'finished'.
content.name: loSk

content.text: The construction of the negative sentence with the present perfect continuous tense happens when we use the word 'not'. The word 'not' comes between the first auxiliary verb and the 'be' verb.
